content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: difficult but good exercise

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Hard one, liked it !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Easy to solve
appealing concept
clear, explanatory description
Enough cases are tested for a clash of code

Hello,
I like this clash.
Is It possible to add a test along the lines of :
"Hello universe or world 19"

Goal
* Please change "latin" to "English".

Output
* Please change "," to "or".

Cases
* Please revise the input in the last pair of cases to contain the character 0 (the output should not be affected).

* Please split the " No message" cases into two pairs. For one pair, the input contains the character 0; for the other pair, the input does not contain 0.

Constraints
* Please add:
0 ≤ each digit in [[message]] ≤ minimum(number of words in [[message]], 9)

Thanks.
Do you mean, a case where one of the indexes is out of bounds? In which case, I'd prefer not to, in order to keep this clash simple :)
OK it's understandable, I'll do the clash one last time later

Just before validating, sorry to be fussy, in the "A few examples" section, could you put in a little more formatting? In particular, in the last example: "{{There is no digits here.}} has no secret message." convert it into : "{{There is no digits here.}} has {{(no secret message)}}."
I've reworded the examples to include not only whether there is a secret message or not, but what the user should print in such cases. Is that correct for you now? :)

Thank you.

I can't say I'm 100% sure I'm correct, but according to my understanding of the Wikipedia entry, the Latin alphabet lacks the letters J, U and W:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_alphabet

But I can say for sure the letters belong to the English alphabet of 26 letters:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_alphabet

Maybe I'm biased due to having used Unicode directly recently (documented some character tables with equivalents to Unicode if exists), but the technical names for such characters are "Latin Capital" and "Latin Small Letter", e.g.:

* Latin Capital Letter W: https://symbl.cc/en/0057/ ("Basic Latin" block, "Uppercase Latin alphabet" subblock)
* Latin Small Letter J: https://symbl.cc/en/006A/ ("Basic Latin" block, "Lowercase Latin alphabet" subblock)

But I can see how that may be confusing to less technical people, so I'll leave it as is :)
